Award.AbstractNarration:
The OpenFlow (OF) protocol is evolving as a standard in the software-defined networking (SDN) paradigm. While high performance networking equipment with OF support is available, continued evolution of the standard means that users may need to augment the functions available in deployed equipment. This augmentation may be performed by network processing units (NPU), or by PC-based solutions. While the network provisioning algorithms for the Global Environment for Network Innovation (GENI) are able to set up OF circuits, they do not currently have the capability of inserting NPUs or other means of function augmentation. This project provides a framework for delivering advanced network functions using NPUs and specifically shows how to use the Cavium network processing unit in ExoGENI racks to provide advanced processing functions at high speed.

The project will provide hooks for enabling the continued use of older OF switches in the face of continued evolution of the OF standard by allowing newer functions to be implemented on NPUs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project, EAGER: Programmable Network Function Instantiaion, is on research investigations and development of resource management along with network function instantiation orchestration over the legacy networks. The PI's current NSF award to build campus cyberinfrastructure (CC-NIE NSF award no. 1341019) has been utilized as the backbone research infrastructure to conduct the resource management software development and investigative efforts. Furthermore, vendor donations in the form of switches (Dell PowerConnect 7048) with an expansion slot that hosts network processor units are evaluated towards deployment possibilities.

Project accomplishments:

1. Testbed design that integrated a network function instantiation software platform.

2. The aggregate manager that runs the resource management and interaction software.

3. Determination of switch access control mappings towards network function instantiation.

4. System integration with the campus network to provide reachability with GENI (Global Environment for Network Innovation - another NSF-funded project, award no. 1346688) testbed.

5. Network function examples to illustrate possible usage scenarios in the research community.

The project involved coordination with the campus IT personnel and organization to facilitate the hosting of network equipment, connectivity requirements, and circuit provisioning to enable a research infrastructure that extends and connects with GENI testbed. The network function instantiation has been achieved to provide on-demand filtering and forwarding capabilities. Demonstration of the achievements has been presented during the GENI Engineering Conference 22: Network Function Instantiation using Virtual Topology Services (VTS). The poster from this conference is attached to this report.

Intellectual merit of this outcome is the knowledge created on instantiating atomic network functions with resource management software towards advanced network experimentation. In addition, integration with existing enterprise systems created new design directions.

Broader impact of the project lies both in enabling advanced applied research in network science and engineering and possible innovative commercial solutions with network functions.
